docs.lead_paragraph: Even as Senate Democrats seemed willing to give up on the idea of a government-run insurance plan, or public option, a war of words broke out on Tuesday between the man credited with originating the idea and the senator who had the strongest hand in killing it. Jacob Hacker, a Yale University political science professor widely regarded as a patriarch of the public option, said in an interview Tuesday that he had been misquoted by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who cited Mr. Hacker's support for a proposed Medicare expansion as a reason to oppose the idea.
docs.abstract: Yale University prof Jacob Hacker, proponent of government-run insurance plan, or public option, says he was misquoted by Sen Joseph Lieberman, who said he opposed compromise proposal to expand Medicare because it was enthusiastically embraced by Hacker and other supporters of public option (M)
docs.snippet: Even as Senate Democrats seemed willing to give up on the idea of a government-run insurance plan, or public option, a war of words broke out on Tuesday between the man credited with originating the idea and the senator who had the strongest hand in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's threat to derail the Senate health care legislation brought a hail of criticism, and some praise, from readers on Tuesday. A sampling of their comments: ''The Senate should be abolished (or reduced to confirming judges). It's an undemocratic relic of the 18th century in which representatives of a tiny minority of the population control the agenda.'' Pam
docs.abstract: Sen Joseph Lieberman's threat to derail Senate health care legislation draws hail of criticism and some praise from readers; sampling of comments (M)
docs.snippet: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's threat to derail the Senate health care legislation brought a hail of criticism, and some praise, from readers on Tuesday. A sampling of their comments:     ''The Senate should be abolished (or reduced to confirming...

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal agents arrested 26 suspects in three states on Tuesday, including a doctor and nurses, in a crackdown on Medicare fraud totaling $61 million. Arrests in three separate cases in Brooklyn, Detroit and Miami included a Florida doctor accused of running a $40 million home health care scheme that falsely listed patients as blind diabetics so he could bill for twice-daily nurse visits.

headline.main: 26 Arrested in Three States In Medicare Fraud Schemes

docs.abstract: Federal agents arrest 26 suspects in three states in crackdown on Medicare fraud totaling $61 million; suspects lined up bogus patients and otherwise billed Medicare for unnecessary medical treatment or equipment; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Federal agents arrested 26 suspects in three states on Tuesday, including a doctor and nurses, in a crackdown on Medicare fraud totaling $61 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the battle over health care lurches toward a conclusion, President Obama is confronting an increasingly sharp divide on the Democratic left, with liberals in the Senate and the House split on a critical question: How much of what they want is enough? In the Senate, where time is running out for Democrats to meet the president's deadline of passing a bill by Christmas, liberals signaled on Tuesday that they would hold their noses and vote for a version of the measure that would strip out some of their most cherished provisions, including an expansion of Medicare and the possibility of a government-run insurance plan.

headline.main: Health Care Talks Show Sharp Democratic Divide

docs.abstract: Pres Obama is confronting increasingly sharp divide among liberal Democrats in Congress over health case legislation; Senate liberals have indicated they will vote for version of measure that strips out some of their most cherished provisions, including expansion of Medicare and government-run insurance program; House liberals have voiced strong opposition to Senate version and appear unwilling to fall in line; photo (M)
docs.snippet: President Obama urged Senate Democrats to bury their differences and pass sweeping health legislation within the next nine days.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG  and ROBERT PEAR; David M. Herszenhorn contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: the former Democrat, current independent from Connecticut -- rejected the so-called public health care option. Then he threatened to torpedo the entire health care reform bill if it allowed people over 55 to buy Medicare plans. The aim of that idea, like the public option, is to provide more choice for consumers and more competition for the private insurance industry. And that industry, you will not be surprised to hear, has been very, very good to Mr. Lieberman.
docs.snippet: Senator Joseph Lieberman’s support for health care reform seems hypocritical. He’s has taken $1 million from the insurance industry and is now against an over-55 Medicare buy-in.

docs.lead_paragraph: Efforts to force the public hospital here to continue providing free dialysis treatment to a group of immigrants, most of them illegal, suffered a setback on Tuesday when a judge dismissed a lawsuit challenging the recent closing of the hospital's outpatient renal clinic. A lawyer for the roughly 50 patients said he would appeal. But the ruling for Grady Memorial Hospital brings the patients closer to a Jan. 3 deadline for finding new sources of the life-sustaining dialysis treatment.

headline.main: Immigrants Lose Lawsuit Against Atlanta Hospital

docs.abstract: Judge dismisses lawsuit challenging recent closure of outpatient renal clinic run by Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta, Ga; group of 50 patients, most of them illegal immigrants, claimed hospital had illegally abandoned them; hospital closed clinic for fiscal reasons in early October, agreeing to pay for three months of dialysis for patients are private clinics, but most of patients have not taken steps to seek treatment alternatives; photo (M)
docs.snippet: About 50 patients, mostly illegal immigrants, had sued to force Grady Memorial Hospital, a struggling public hospital that provides charity care, to continue providing free dialysis treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the legislative tussle over how to trim Medicare to help pay for a health care overhaul, the Democratic leadership has singled out the subsidies that private insurers receive under the Medicare Advantage program. Few lawmakers seem to realize, however, that the program is already shrinking, thanks to new legal and regulatory changes. In 2010, there will be 18 percent fewer Medicare Advantage plans available to older Americans than there were in 2009, according to an analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation. Seven percent of the roughly 10 million beneficiaries enrolled in these plans will have to switch, according to the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
docs.abstract: Democratic leaders in Congress have singled out subsidies that private insurers receive under Medicare Advantage program as one area of Medicare spending that could be cut to help pay for health care overhaul; few lawmakers seem to realize that program is already shrinking as result of legal and regulatory changes (M)
docs.snippet: In the legislative tussle over how to trim Medicare to help pay for a health care overhaul, the Democratic leadership has singled out the subsidies that private insurers receive under the Medicare Advantage program. Few lawmakers seem to realize,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as Senate Democrats seemed willing to give up on the idea of a government-run insurance plan, or public option, a war of words broke out Tuesday between the man credited with originating the idea and the senator who had the strongest hand in killing it.
docs.abstract: The father of the public option vs. Joe Lieberman, on what neither of them may have said and when they didn't say it.
docs.snippet: The father of the public option vs. Joe Lieberman, on what neither of them may have said and when they didn't say it.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Monday, when it looked like Joe Lieberman's refusal to vote for a public option (or anything remotely like it) might derail health care reform, Ezra Klein kicked up a hornet's nest of controversy by accusing Lieberman of being "willing to cause the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people in order to settle an old electoral score." That "hundreds of thousands" refers to the number of Americans who die every decade because they don't have health insurance - or rather, it refers to one study's estimate of that number. Other studies, cited by Michael Cannon and John Goodman, suggest that the number is considerably closer to zero - or else that the link between health insurance and mortality might be too murky too penetrate. But of course there are still other studies that tend to confirm Ezra's numbers ...
docs.abstract: Are opponents of health care reform responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths?
docs.snippet: Are opponents of health care reform responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths?

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of more than 260 workers on Broadway - cleaners, porters and matrons (bathroom attendants) at some 30 theaters - inched closer to the possibility of a strike on Tuesday afternoon. A unanimous vote, in which more than 200 members of the local 32 BJ of the Service Employees International Union participated, gave the union bargaining committee the authority to settle or strike. The workers are involved in negotiations with the Broadway League, which represents theater owners, and are demanding a pay raise of $1.50 an hour, a promise not to see their health insurance cut and additional pension benefits. The union's contract expires on Dec. 31, though a spokesman said the last scheduled bargaining date with the Broadway League was this Thursday. The actor Jimmy Smits, who is currently starring in "God of Carnage" at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, addressed the workers who were voting in a midtown hotel and urged them to "fight for what's fair and just."

headline.main: Broadway Service Workers Give Union Authority to Strike or Settle

docs.abstract: A group of more than 260 workers on Broadway - cleaners, porters and matrons at some 30 theaters - inched closer to the possibility of a strike on Tuesday afternoon.
